bibl.title: Territory of Washington v. Mary E. Teller. C. S. Renfield Testimony
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.
Multiple case files included with habeas petition

msIdentifier.repository: Washington State Archives, Eastern Regional Branch
msIdentifier.collection: Spokane County Government; Clerk, Territorial Case Files, 1879-1889

div1.p:
Am Cornerer of Spokane County held inquest about 1/2 mile west of Deep Creek Falls on the body supposed to be of Frank Teller and I saw John Duggan testified before the coroner jury then on 31st of May has heard a part of his testimony this morning place I speak of is same place he spoke of Shown Diagram and explained to him says diagram substantially correct first saw deceased Wednesday June 1/87 he was lying upon his face hands underneath him with left side of his face exposed to view no indications that he had been moved - nothing to indicate to that he had been moved with house where he was lying path was dusty - pool of blood under head having evidently come from nostrils - I cant say presicely how long he had been there should say here he was rigid no blood flowing could not state how long since it did - saw blood between front steps and houses one pool larger than other - mark shape say 3 inches long and a little irregular notice carefully others in close proximity to the others hand say 4 or five feet from front door - Has no blood between deceased and front gate - I in the examination — We remove all of his clothes
to and examine closely for bullet wounds supposing he had been shot examining for the benefit of the jury and a found no bullet holes any where in the body lowest mark of violence on the chest near the heart about size peices dark blue looked like he had been struck with something - I could not tell whether made by pistol or not shown pistol - not a in jury dont think him down - was another think somewhere about the shoulder with not so regular nothing serious did not examine for bullet hole in clothing found small holes just behind right ear about midway first glancing supposed it to be bullet hole - took knife I made one from wound up one down took the two flaps and decided there up & back & down and back so that we might examine the skull found no trace of bullet when the skull properly smooth and intact - Wound evidently had been made by that slat and the ear had suffered from that blow that was the only mark - Examined skull and found throughout comminuted by that I mean broken in small pieces say past upon the left side large indication could almost put the back of your hands on left side no other mark of violence - examined nostril mouth and eye for bullet but no mark of any whether
X 2 wounds on body might have been made by a spent bullet Never had experience with this hit in that location on the heart my opinion is expertly spoken does not think if clothing on and hit sufficient to cause this mark think it would knock him down - average thickness of an adult mans skull would say from my experience say 1/4 or 3/8 and 1/2 inch - The skull varies in thickness — there is different in thickness in skull of different people

Re X
It would depend somewhat on the weight and momentum - supposing a man was struck sufficiently with and in as much weighing 1/2 an ounce to produce the described would it knock him down - I think not it might knock him down - Death results from fracture of the skull producing both concussion and compression of the brain
